maml:description.maml:para: Disables BidTrace for Windows DAC.
The Disable-WdacBidTrace cmdlet disables Built-in Diagnostics Tracing (BidTrace) for troubleshooting Windows Data Access Components (Windows DAC).
For more information about data access tracing, see Data Access Tracing (Windows 8) (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh829624aspx)on the Microsoft Developer Network.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies a folder. This cmdlet disables BidTrace for applications under the folder that this parameter specifies.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet disables BidTrace for the Windows DAC BidTrace settings that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Indicates that this cmdlet applies to all applications. If you specify this parameter, the cmdlet disables BidTrace for all applications.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet disables BidTrace for the Windows DAC BidTrace settings that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the input object that is used in a pipeline command.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the full path for an application. This cmdlet disables BidTrace for the application that this parameter specifies.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet disables BidTrace for the Windows DAC BidTrace settings that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.
Specifies a process ID. This cmdlet disables BidTrace for the process that has the ID that this parameter specifies.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies a folder. This cmdlet disables BidTrace for applications under the folder that this parameter specifies.
Indicates that this cmdlet applies to all applications. If you specify this parameter, the cmdlet disables BidTrace for all applications.
Specifies the input object that is used in a pipeline command.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the full path for an application. This cmdlet disables BidTrace for the application that this parameter specifies.

Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet disables BidTrace for the Windows DAC BidTrace settings that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.
Specifies a process ID. This cmdlet disables BidTrace for the process that has the ID that this parameter specifies.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: ----- Example 1: Disable BidTrace for a 32-bit application -----

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command disables the BidTrace for the application C:\temp\abc.exe on the 32-bit platform.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Disable BidTrace for a 32-bit application by using a Process ID

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command disables the BidTrace for the application C:\temp\abc.exe on the 32-bit platform, and disables BidTrace for the particular instance of abc.exe that has the Process ID 1234.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Disable BidTrace for all native applications in a folder

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command disables the BidTrace for all applications in C:\temp on the native platform.

command:example.maml:title: --- Example 4: Disable BidTrace for all 64-bit applications ---

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command disables the BidTrace for all 64-bit applications.

command:example.maml:title: Example 5: Enable and disable BidTrace for a 64-bit application
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $BidSetting = Enable-WdacBidTrace -Path "C:\temp\abc.exe" -Platform "64-bit" -PassThru PS C:\> Disable-WdacBidTrace -InputObject $BidSetting

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command enables the BidTrace for the 64-bit application C:\temp\abc.exe, and then stores the result in the $BidSetting variable. After you run the first command, you can use abc.exe.
The second command disables BidTrace for the application stored in $BidSetting.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables BidTrace for troubleshooting Windows DAC.
The Enable-WdacBidTrace cmdlet enables Built-in Diagnostics Tracing (BidTrace) for troubleshooting Windows Data Access Components (Windows DAC).
For more information about data access tracing, see Data Access Tracing (Windows 8) (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh829624aspx)on the Microsoft Developer Network.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies a folder. This cmdlet enables BidTrace for all applications under the folder that this cmdlet specifies.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet enables BidTrace for the WDAC BidTrace settings that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

command:example.maml:title: - Example 1: Enable BidTrace for an application on a platform -

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command enables the BidTrace for the application C:\temp\abc.exe on the 32-bit platform.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Enable BidTrace for application by using a Process ID

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command enables the BidTrace for the application C:\temp\abc.exe on the 32-bit platform for a particular instance of abc.exe. The enabled application has the Process ID 1234.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Enable BidTrace for applications in a specified folder on the native platform

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command enables a BidTrace for all applications located in C:\temp on the native platform.
This command enables the BidTrace for all 64-bit applications.

command:example.maml:title: -- Example 5: Enable and disable BidTrace for an application --
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $BidSetting = Enable-WdacBidTrace -Path "C:\temp\abc.exe" -Platform "64-bit" -PassThru PS C:\> Disable-WdacBidTrace -InputObject $BidSetting

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command enables the BidTrace for the 64-bit application C:\temp\abc.exe, and then stores the result in the $BidSetting variable. After you run the first command, you can use abc.exe.
The second command disables BidTrace for the application stored in $BidSetting.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets BidTrace settings.
The Get-WdacBidTrace cmdlet gets a list of Built-in Diagnostics Tracing (BidTrace) settings for different applications.
For more information about data access tracing, see Data Access Tracing (Windows 8) (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh829624aspx)on the Microsoft Developer Network.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies a folder. This cmdlets gets Windows DAC BidTrace settings that are associated with the folder that this parameter specifies. You can use wildcard characters.
Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet gets Windows DAC BidTrace settings that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Indicates that this cmdlet applies to all applications. If you specify this parameter, the cmdlet gets Windows DAC BidTrace settings for with all applications.
Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet gets Windows DAC BidTrace settings that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Specifies the full path for an application. This cmdlet gets Windows Data Access Components (Windows DAC) BidTrace settings for the application that this parameter specifies. You can use wildcard characters. If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet gets all Windows DAC BidTrace settings.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet gets Windows DAC BidTrace settings that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

Specifies a process ID. This cmdlet gets Windows DAC BidTrace settings for the process that has the ID that this parameter specifies. If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet gets all Windows DAC BidTrace settings.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies a folder. This cmdlets gets Windows DAC BidTrace settings that are associated with the folder that this parameter specifies. You can use wildcard characters.
Indicates that this cmdlet applies to all applications. If you specify this parameter, the cmdlet gets Windows DAC BidTrace settings for with all applications.

Specifies the full path for an application. This cmdlet gets Windows Data Access Components (Windows DAC) BidTrace settings for the application that this parameter specifies. You can use wildcard characters. If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet gets all Windows DAC BidTrace settings.
Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet gets Windows DAC BidTrace settings that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

Specifies a process ID. This cmdlet gets Windows DAC BidTrace settings for the process that has the ID that this parameter specifies. If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet gets all Windows DAC BidTrace settings.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all BidTrace settings for both 32-bit and 64-bit platforms.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get the BidTrace setting for an application on a platform

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the BidTrace setting for the application C:\temp\abc.exe and the specific settings for all its process instances on the 32-bit platform.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Get the BidTrace setting for an application by using a Process ID

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the BidTrace setting for the application C:\temp\abc.exe that has the Process ID 1234 on the 64-bit platform.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Get the BidTrace setting for an application by using a wildcard character

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the BidTrace setting for the specified application on the 64-bit platform. The Path parameter uses a wildcard character.

command:example.maml:title: Example 5: Get the BidTrace setting for application in a specified folder

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the BidTrace setting for the application located inside C:\temp on the 32-bit platform.

command:example.maml:title: Example 6: Get the BidTrace setting for application in a folder that includes a wildcard character

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the BidTrace setting for the application in the specified location on the 32-bit platform. The Path parameter uses a wildcard character.

command:example.maml:title: Example 7: Get the BidTrace settings for all 32-bit applications

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the BidTrace settings for all 32-bit applications on the computer.

command:example.maml:title: ----- Example 8: Get BidTrace settings for both platforms -----

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all BidTrace settings for both 32-bit and 64-bit platforms, and then store the results in the $BidArray variable.
